Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz NMR to Support the Multidisciplinary Research and Education at University of Massachusetts Dartmouth
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Maolin Guo from University of Massachussetts, Dartmouth and colleagues Emmanuel Ojadi, Catherine Neto, Sivappa Rasapalli and David Manke will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) bioinorganic chemistry; (b) natural products; (c) organic synthesis and asymmetric catalysis; (d) inorganic chemistry including MOFs; and (e) DNA adduct formation in plants.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research at the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth and neighboring academic institutions, industries and local high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth received a $339,000 Major Research Instrument award from NSF for the acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer, a primary means of characterizing organic molecules, inorganic compounds and biomolecules. In addition to purchasing the 400 MHz digital NMR spectrometer from Bruker Biospin, this NSF award catalyzed the hiring of a University-funded full time NMR manager/lecturer and matching funds from the University which enabled the purchasing of an additional bench-top E-Scan EPR (Electron Paramagnetic Resonance) spectrometer from Bruker Biospin. The NMR and EPR spectrometers represent a major step forward in the department's ability to perform research, attract faculty, students and collaborations.

 

This new 400 MHz NMR and the E-Scan EPR have enabled the development new bioimaging sensors for detecting metal ions and reactive oxygen/nitrogen species which is involved in many diseases like cancer, cardiovascular and neurological disorders; novel ansamycins, imidazopyrimidines with anti-bacterial activities; metal-organic frameworks as new energy materials and novel complexes as new battery materials. Many of these research outcomes have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals or presented in national or international conferences. In addition, numerous undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral/visiting scholars received NMR training on this instrument and some of them heavily relied on the NMR for their thesis work. Eleven MS thesis and 5 PhD dissertations were produced during this project period. Many of these graduates have been placed in postdoctoral positions in academia (Harvard Medical School, UMass Medical School, etc) or jobs in Biotech and Pharma industry (Waters Corp, Biogen, Primera Analytical, etc). Also a significant number of undergraduates whose research was heavily dependent on the NMR have been placed in significant doctoral programs (MIT, Brandeis, Brown, Texas A&M, Ohio State, NC, etc), as well as the award of an NSF GRFP to one of the undergraduate researchers.
